subject: Real Estate
title: The Gadsden Purchase
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Gadsden Purchase.

hook.text: In 1853, the U.S. bought a strip of land from Mexico for $10 million â€” to build a railroad.

buildup.text: The Gadsden Purchase added 29,670 square miles of desert that would become southern Arizona and New Mexico.

discovery.text: The railroad needed flat terrain, and the only feasible southern route ran through Mexican territory.

twist.text: Mexico's president Santa Anna sold the land to fund his struggling government. He was overthrown shortly after.

climax.text: The Gadsden Purchase was the last major land acquisition that completed the contiguous United States.

punchline.text: A railroad route completed a nation's borders.

quiz.question: Why did the U.S. make the Gadsden Purchase?
options: To build a southern railroad route
